question:
Why Pluto was removed from the category of planets?
  1. It shares its orbit with Neptune
  2. Its gravity is not enough to keep it in spherical shape
Select the correct option from the codes given below:
explanation:
The International Astronomical Union (IAU) has defined three conditions for a celestial object to be called a planet. The three conditions prescribed by the IAU are
  • It must orbit the Sun.
  • It should be massive enough to acquire an approximately spherical shape.
  • It has to clear its orbit i.e. it must be the object that exerts the maximum gravitational pull within its orbit.  If an object ventures close to a planet’s orbit, it will either collide with it and be accreted or would be ejected out. 
Why Pluto was removed from the category of planets?
  • Pluto is affected by Neptune’s gravity.
  • Pluto shares its orbit with the frozen objects in the Kuiper belt.
As a result Pluto was removed from the category of planets and was termed as dwarf planet as Dwarf planets need satisfy other two conditions only. About International Astronomical Union: The mission of the IAU is to promote and safeguard the science of astronomy in all its aspects through international cooperation. It was founded in 1919.
